I’ll be joining my Texas colleagues in getting to the bottom of what happened so it never happens again. 

In the meantime, please stay warm, stay safe, and stay strong.

All of this calls into question our ability in Texas to prepare for extreme weather events and plan power accordingly, so we’re not relying on frozen wind turbines to heat our homes during a blizzard.
It also raises serious concerns about the push to decommission baseload power sources like natural gas, which are more reliable than wind and are critical right now to keeping the lights on in Texas.
This raises serious concerns about the reliability of renewable-reliant power grids during extreme weather.

Bottom line: Thank God for baseload energy made up of fossil fuels. 

Had our grid been more reliant on the wind turbines that froze, the outages would have been much worse.

We had every natural gas plant—that wasn’t already down for maintenance—online generating power. Gov. Abbott made the right call in diverting all natural gas to home heating fuel and then electricity for homes. Gas and coal brought a stable supply of energy, but still not enough.

#3 - Low Supply of Natural Gas: 

ERCOT planned on 67GW from natural gas/coal, but could only get 43GW of it online. We didn’t run out of natural gas, but we ran out of the ability to get natural gas. Pipelines in Texas don’t use cold insulation – so things were freezing.

Even though the system was stable, the reactor shut off because the sensor couldn’t relay that the system was stable. This is just one of the many mechanisms that makes nuclear energy so safe, even though it interfered with our ability to get backup power.

#2 - Even Nuclear Got Cold: We only have 4 nuclear units in TX, 2 near Houston and 2 near Dallas. At the plant near Houston, one of the two reactors at the plant turned off – due to a precaution because a safety sensor froze.

This is what happens when you force the grid to rely in part on wind as a power source. When weather conditions get bad as they did this week, intermittent renewable energy like wind isn’t there when you need it.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/salgilbertie/2021/02/15/texas-outages-put-reliability-of-renewable-energy-in-the-spotlight/
To make matters worse, existing storage of wind energy in batteries was also gone, because batteries were losing 60% of their energy in the cold.

#1 - Frozen Wind Turbines: 

West Texas, where most of the wind energy is focused, had wind turbines that had to be de-iced. The little energy that power regulators planned on wind to supply was now gone.

With electricity blackouts across Texas, many are wondering: what happened? How does the energy capital of the United States run out of power?

Here’s what happened. THREAD

I will continue to work across all levels of government to make sure North Texas has the resources we need to weather this crisis and to make sure that North Texans are aware of and able to access them.

ERCOT is reporting scams circulating on social media asking for Texans to text their personal account numbers. ERCOT does not need any of your personal information to restore your power, please do not text these scammers.

As another bitter cold night begins, there are warming centers open throughout North Texas. You can find a full list here: https://tdem.texas.gov/warming-centers/. The @TexasGuard is working to transport Texans to warming centers when necessary. You can also dial 2-1-1 to find centers near you.

Right now, FEMA is providing generators, blankets, and water to save lives while this storm persists. The most important role FEMA will play in this effort will be to make sure resources are available to help us recover from the widespread damage.

Today, I spoke with @fema officials and got an update on their efforts in North Texas. They emphasized the need to share information about available resources. I will continue to update my pages with resources available to keep folks safe and warm and encourage you to share them.

There are many questions that remain unanswered and I will continue to press for answers and update North Texans as I get them to ensure we stay safe now and prevent this from happening in the future. At this moment, we all must do what we can to keep each other safe and warm.

North Texans are resilient and I am inspired by the ways our communities have come together to weather this storm. If you're able to help a loved one stay warm today, please do so, we will get through this together. 
https://www.dallasnews.com/news/weather/2021/02/16/neighbors-helping-neighbors-record-cold-is-the-latest-challenge-that-north-texans-have-had-to-pull-together-to-overcome/

Extended and rotating power outages are expected to continue through today. If you lose power, stay warm by closing window blinds or curtains, putting towels under cracks in doors and windows to keep heat in and wearing layers of lightweight, warm clothing.https://www.wfaa.com/article/weather/staying-warm-when-the-power-is-out/287-5ff13977-5ffe-4b43-ba29-8ab45ce678f3

And I have no doubt you would have extended that same drive to elect Senators @Ossoff and @ReverendWarnock too. 

I wish you could have experienced that. But, the laws you could have worked to change failed us long before you were given the chance to save others. (7/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuW0nS1XMAAe_aF.jpg

Maybe you could’ve been an organizer right here in Georgia working to turn our state blue for President @JoeBiden and Vice President @KamalaHarris. You had that fight and drive in you. (6/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuW0VpMXcAAd4PW.jpg

I think a lot about that as I do this work. But if you were still here, it probably would be you. No, I don’t think you’d have run for office (yet!). But you would be working to change what’s broken in our country. (5/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuWz5HLXYAcoUP3.jpg

President @BarackObama had just been re-elected, and you had such hope that you’d get the chance to vote for someone who looked like you and me one day, too.

I always had such big dreams for you. I just knew you would be the one to fight for change in our community. (4/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuWzo_BXMAID61g.jpg

What I’m left with are your memories and imaginations of what could be.

You were just 85 days short of your 18th birthday – right on the verge of finally getting the right to vote. I know you understood how sacred that right was. (3/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuWzCXdXMAY_rJS.jpg

...but I would give anything just to hug you and hear your voice once more.

I often think about where we would be and what we would be doing if you hadn’t been taken from us far too soon — before you even entered adulthood. (2/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuWuOz1XUAI8XZO.jpg

#1: It’s a once in a century weather event. California has constant energy problems and high prices. 

#2: The reason for blackouts is complex, but in summary: Texas took too many lessons from Cali, over-subsidized renewables, & pushed out baseload energy like natural gas.

For all the sanctimonious leftists who think they “owned Texas,” you know Cali deals with this ALL the time? Even without rare weather events.

Bottom line: Texas’s biggest mistake was learning too many renewable energy lessons from California.

See thread https://twitter.com/dancrenshawtx/status/1361810434282704898?s=21 https://twitter.com/blkahn/status/1361682617448423427 QT @blkahn Representative Dan Crenshaw: "Alexa, show me what happens when you let Democrats control energy policy."
https://twitter.com/DanCrenshawTX/status/1303364789603889154

I’ll be joining my Texas colleagues in getting to the bottom of what happened. We can do better, even for once in a century events.

In the meantime, stay warm, stay safe, and stay strong.
The push to decommission baseload power sources like natural gas would be disastrous when trying to keep the lights on in Texas.

This raises the obvious question: can we ever rely on renewables to power the grid during extreme weather?

No, you need gas or nuclear. 

And subsidizing investment in wind has pushed gas and nuclear out. 

Now we live with the consequences.

Bottom line: fossil fuels are the only thing that saved us. They are *base load* energy.

If we were even *more* reliant on the wind turbines that froze, the outages would have been much worse.

Why don’t we have extra gas power when we need it most? 

Because years of federal subsidies for wind has caused an over reliance on wind and an under-investment in new gas and nuclear plants.

Every natural gas plant stayed online. The “downed” plants were due to scheduled maintenance. 

Gov. Abbott made the right call in diverting all natural gas to home heating fuel and then electricity for homes. Gas and coal brought a stable supply of energy, but still not enough.

#3 - We don’t have enough Natural Gas online: 

ERCOT planned on 67GW from natural gas/coal, but could only get 43GW of it online. We didn’t run out of natural gas, but we lost the ability to get it transported. Pipelines in Texas don’t use cold insulation – so they froze.
(On another note, this shows how safe nuclear is. Lots of safety precautions.)

#2 - Nuclear also got too cold: We only have 4 nuclear units in TX, near Houston and Dallas. One of the reactors near Houston turned off due to a safety sensor freezing. No problem with the reactor. But the lack of the sensor forced the plant to shutdown, as a precaution.

This is what happens when you force the grid to rely in part on wind as a power source. When weather conditions get bad as they did this week, intermittent renewable energy like wind isn’t there when you need it.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/salgilbertie/2021/02/15/texas-outages-put-reliability-of-renewable-energy-in-the-spotlight/

To make matters worse, existing storage of wind energy in batteries was also gone, because batteries were losing 60% of their energy in the cold.

Bottom line: renewables don’t work well in extreme weather. Never will.

#1 - Frozen Wind Turbines: 

West Texas had wind turbines that had to be de-iced. The little energy that power regulators planned on being supplied from wind was now gone.

We have almost 31GW of wind installed on the grid, but on Monday we couldn’t even depend on 6 GW working.

Summary:

A mix of over-subsidized wind energy and under-investment in gas power means we didn’t have enough base load energy for a massive spike in demand.

Also, Texas infrastructure isn’t designed for once-in-a-century freezes.

With  blackouts across Texas, many are wondering: what happened? 

Leftists are cheering a “red state” having energy problems.

Here’s the truth about what happened. THREAD

Ms. Hudnell was not only a teacher and historian, she was a self-taught artist and musician who did original artwork for Black clubs where Cab Calloway and Duke Ellington performed. She was "a lady amongst ladies," and volunteered to teach adults who lacked important skills.

In West Palm Beach, a local teacher became the collector and archivist of decades of forgotten Black history. ❄ Hypothermia: Shivering, exhaustion, confusion.
 ✅ Warm the center of the body. Keep dry & wrap in blankets.

Our bill requires the @FCC to create rules to allow domestic violence survivors to separate their mobile phone line from a group plan without penalties and take other steps to protect them from their abusers.
 
Read more on the bill in my weekly column: https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/weekly-column?ID=D3E99B4C-8B62-4CD1-8F0C-9CFEC95457E4
Senator @BrianSchatz and I have introduced the bipartisan Safe Connections Act to help survivors separate from their abusers.

When you’re stuck in the same house as your abusive partner, technology can be your only lifeline to the outside world. Many of these victims share a cell phone plan with their abusers, who see a shared phone bill, where they can often see every call and text.

According to the @Ne_Coalition, there has been an increase in victims seeking help during COVID. In the 12-month period ending on 9/30/20, the programs they assist across Nebraska received 40,000 calls to their hotline.

We have an obligation to protect our workers and fellow citizens. This common-sense proposal will give millions of Americans the raise they deserve.

Our proposal gradually raises the minimum wage without costing jobs and then sets it to increase automatically with inflation.
 
This minimum-wage increase will go into effect after the pandemic has ended and include protections for small businesses.

At the same time, Congress hasn’t raised the minimum wage in more than a decade, so the paychecks of our poorest workers buy less than they did in 2009.

This is leaving many Americans behind.

Today, Americans have to compete against millions of illegal immigrants who take illegally low wages under the table.
 
We can fix this by requiring employers to verify the legal status of every worker so they can’t undercut Americans on the black market.

Millions of Americans are struggling to make ends meet. I’m introducing a bill w/ @SenatorRomney to give them a raise by increasing the minimum wage and ensuring businesses can't hire illegal immigrants - protecting American workers.

I will keep working to get these answers to help Texans right now and to prevent the same missteps from leaving Texans without power in the increasingly common severe weather events we will face.
(4) why were ERCOT’s predictions for peak use in the winter so far off? We set a record for winter usage on Sunday but are still below summer peak usage.

(3) why was the public not notified sooner about potential outages and the need to take emergency steps to mitigate their own usage? For example, Dallas’s skyline was lit up while some Dallas residents were freezing.
(2) why was there no plan for responding to an emergency loss of some power generation? To have so many generating units go offline without any notice makes emergency planning impossible.

This is unacceptable. ERCOT manages the grid and overall load, and acted to prevent a catastrophic blackout. Here is what we need to find out: (1) why were the generation units not prepared for this weather event? This is a bad storm, but not historic.
I’m on a call with ERCOT right now and have been told that the crisis we are in was caused by unprecedented demand for power and power generation units going offline due to the weather.

President Biden cannot waver – his message and actions need to focus on reopening schools as quickly as possible. After a full year out of the classrooms for many students, there’s too much at stake to keep them on the sidelines. (5/5)

I know the uncertainty is difficult for our teachers who are working so hard to deal with the challenges of COVID, which is why last month I urged Governor Inslee to make teachers a priority for vaccination. (4/5)
That’s not the “bold and ambitious” reopening plan President Biden promised. I’ve helped secure over $70 billion in Congress to give schools the tools they need. (3/5)

It emphasizes mitigation strategies like proper distancing & mask wearing and others – but states that schools should be the first to open and last to close.
Yet the president’s spokesperson said last week that reopening schools means “one day a week” for 51% of schools. (2/5)

Last week I urged President Biden to avoid backtracking on his goal to open schools. On Friday, the CDC put out more guidance based on the best available data reinforcing that schools can reopen safely. (1/5)

I invite you to join me in continuing to celebrate Justan by joining us at a virtual event held in honor of him, his fellow Honorees and #BHM on Friday, February 26. Go to https://www.casey.senate.gov/BHM to learn more and to RSVP.

Justan, along with his partner Kevin, founded Change Now, a local non-profit organization serving the greater Lehigh Valley that focuses on caring for the unsheltered population and serving families in need.

He has partnered with the City of Allentown to review their Use of Force policy, spoken at colleges across the Lehigh Valley about his activism and provided testimony for the Democratic Policy Committee in Harrisburg.

From there, he organized & participated in additional Black Lives Matter marches, and formed a collective with local community & nonprofit leaders, so they could brainstorm new initiatives for racial justice, equity and equality for Black and Brown residents in the Lehigh Valley.

What started out as an idea to gather a few of his friends downtown to march for the deaths of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, turned into hundreds attending including the mayor, chief of police and members of local government.
Justan founded Black Lives Matter Lehigh Valley this past summer after organizing the city’s first BLM march along with longtime friend Shaqwanna Griffin.

Justan was born in Scranton, and relocated with his family to Allentown at the age of five. He is a product of the Allentown School District and currently resides in the city with his partner, Kevin, and his two children, Shyllee and Shamaer.

@short_pants @EricBanta @ERCOT_ISO Yeah - and keep in mind that when the polar vortex hit in 2012 it hugely disrupted coal (rail) deliveries.  No fuel supply chain is immune from extreme weather disruption.
11/ Anyway, that's all I got on this for now.  But follow @JesseJenkins for continuing analysis on this week in TX.  I definitely will!  /fin

10/ So while gas dependency + lower pipeline supply reliability standards have the potential to create problems everywhere, Texas' grid structure makes them uniquely vulnerable.  The cold snap exposed that vulnerability.

9/ Texas is particularly exposed to this because it is a stand-alone grid.  (The US "grid" is really 3 grids: Eastern, Western and Texas.  AKA, ERCOT.)  https://www.energy.gov/oe/services/electricity-policy-coordination-and-implementation/transmission-planning/recovery-act-0

8/ But our gas grid has no equivalent standard.  Nor for that matter does our coal delivery infrastructure.  That means that as grids become increasingly reliant on natural gas supply, the gas supply infrastructure becomes the reliability bottleneck.

7/ ...making sure you can continue to meet demand if your largest single generator goes down and designing a system that provides electricity with 3 - 5 9s reliability (e.g., 99.9% - 99.999% online).  See here for details: https://www.nerc.com/pa/Stand/Pages/default.aspx

6/ If you are an electric distributor or provider with responsibility for a given electric control region, you are required to maintain exceptionally high reliability standards.  Those include but are not limited to...
5/ So far, this is just what Jesse said but in more tweets.  But there's also another factor at play that bears mention: reliability guidelines.
4/ Texas isn't used to planning for cold snaps, but they are gas-dependent on the power grid.  So they are, in essence, acting like New England right now.

3/ In most of the country, the tightest times for power markets are during hot summer days when demand peaks to run all that AC. In New England, the tightest times are often cold winter days when supply gets constrained as the gas is redirected to heat
2/ New England - a region that is both cold and has long been more reliant than others on natural gas for power generation - has had to grapple with this for a long time.

1/ As Jesse notes, natural gas is somewhat unique in that it is both a power plant fuel and a home heating fuel.  When cold weather comes, regulators bias in favor of heating rather than power generation.

She spoke truth to power every day, and now it’s up to us to carry her legacy forward. I extend my deepest condolences to the family, friends, and loved ones of Doris Bunte. We have all been blessed to have had her touch our lives.

From her leadership desegregating the Boston Housing Authority, to her advocacy for Roxbury Community College, and her legacy creating Massachusetts’ first majority-Black State Senate district, Doris dedicated her life and career to the fight for justice.

She taught me life-long lessons about the dignity of a safe home, the power of womanhood, and the rights of every person to lift themselves up and make a better world.

All of us in Massachusetts owe this history-maker and trailblazer endless gratitude.

Doris Bunte was a fearless pioneer in the Massachusetts State House who never wavered in her commitment to the principles she believed in – justice, integrity, access to opportunity. When we served together in the State House, she was counsel, inspiration, and friend.

When there was no path, Doris Bunte charted one. When there was no example, Doris Bunte became one. When there was no choice, Doris Bunte made history. 
https://www.bostonglobe.com/2021/02/16/metro/groundbreaking-black-woman-state-city-government-doris-bunte-dies-87/
